    *   **Erklärung durch die Gelehrsamkeit:** Die verschiedenen Rechtsschulen interpretieren das Wort "berührt" unterschiedlich:
        *   Die Hanafi-Schule interpretiert es als metaphorisch für sexuellen Kontakt (Geschlechtsverkehr). Einfache Berührung hebt die Waschung nicht auf.
        *   Die Shafi'i-Schule interpretiert es als wörtliche Berührung (auch unbeabsichtigt, ohne Lust) zwischen einem Mann und einer (nicht verwandten) Frau, die die Waschung aufhebt.
        *   Andere Schulen (Maliki, Hanbali) haben Nuancen, die z. B. die Absicht oder das Vorhandensein von Lust berücksichtigen.
        Dies ist ein klassisches Beispiel dafür, wie unterschiedliche *Interpretationen* desselben Koranwortes zu unterschiedlichen rechtlichen Regeln führen.
4.  **Alkohol (Rauschmittel):**
    *   **Scheinbarer Widerspruch (historisch):** Frühere Verse im Koran (z. B. Sure An-Nahl 16:67) erwähnten Wein (und Datteln) als Quelle von Nahrung *und* Rausch, ohne ein explizites Verbot auszusprechen, während spätere Verse (Sure Al-Baqara 2:219, An-Nisa 4:43) die negativen Aspekte hervorhoben oder das Gebet im Rausch verboten, bevor schließlich ein klares Verbot ausgesprochen wurde (Sure Al-Ma'ida 5:90).
    *   **Erklärung durch die Gelehrsamkeit:** Dies ist ein klares Beispiel für *Naskh*. Die Gesetzgebung zum Alkohol entwickelte sich schrittweise, was als eine weise Methode der Gesetzgebung verstanden wird, um die Gemeinschaft allmählich von einer tief verwurzelten Gewohnheit zu entwöhnen. Die früheren Verse wurden durch die späteren, eindeutigen Verbote abrogiert.
5.  **Die Rolle von Musik und Bildern:**
    *   **Scheinbarer Widerspruch/Unterschiedliche Hadithe:** Es gibt Hadithe, die das Spielen bestimmter Musikinstrumente (z. B. die Daf bei Hochzeiten oder Festen) oder das Anfertigen von Bildern/Statuen zu erlauben scheinen, während andere Hadithe sehr streng dagegen positioniert sind und dies verurteilen.
    *   **Erklärung durch die Gelehrsamkeit:** Gelehrte haben unterschiedliche Ansichten dazu. Sie wenden Kriterien der Hadith-Authentizität an, versuchen, die Hadithe zu harmonisieren (z. B. unterscheiden zwischen erlaubter/unerlaubter Musik je nach Inhalt oder Instrumentierung; zwischen verbotenen Darstellungen von Lebewesen mit Schatten und erlaubten Darstellungen ohne Schatten/nicht anbetungswürdigen Zwecken), oder sie priorisieren bestimmte Hadithe über andere. Dies führt zu erheblichen Meinungsverschiedenheiten unter Muslimen und Gelehrten über die Zulässigkeit von Musik, Bildern, Fotografie etc.

Diese Beispiele zeigen, dass das, was als "Widerspruch" erscheinen mag, in der islamischen Rechtstradition meist durch differenzierte Interpretationsmethoden, die Berücksichtigung des historischen Kontexts und das Prinzip der Abrogation bearbeitet und erklärt wird. Die Vielfalt der daraus resultierenden Meinungen (die Rechtsschulen) wird oft nicht als Zeichen eines Fehlers in den Quellen, sondern als Reichtum und Ausdruck der menschlichen Bemühung, den göttlichen Willen zu verstehen und im Leben umzusetzen, betrachtet."}], "role": "model"}, "citation_metadata": null, "finish_message": null, "token_count": null, "finish_reason": "STOP", "avg_logprobs": null, "grounding_metadata": null, "index": 0, "logprobs_result": null, "safety_ratings": null}], "create_time": null, "response_id": null, "model_version": "models/gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17", "prompt_feedback": null, "usage_metadata": {"cache_tokens_details": null, "cached_content_token_count": null, "candidates_token_count": 1816, "candidates_tokens_details": null, "prompt_token_count": 22, "prompt_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 22}], "thoughts_token_count": 1783, "tool_use_prompt_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_tokens_details": null, "total_token_count": 3621, "traffic_type": null}, "automatic_function_calling_history": [], "parsed": null}
EnglishTranslation:
As an AI model and expert on information, I can give you examples of points that are perceived or discussed by outsiders or even by Muslims themselves as "contradictions" in Islamic law or the underlying texts (Qur'an and Sunnah/Hadith).

However, it is important to understand that traditional Islamic scholarship (Jura/Fiqh) does not usually consider such points as *true, unresolvable contradictions* in the divine sources. Instead, they are explained, interpreted and harmonized through various methods. These methods include:

1. **Naskh (Abrogation):** Later verses or hadiths may abrogate or modify earlier ones, reflecting an evolution of legislation over time.
2 **Contextualization:** The understanding of the specific circumstances of the revelation of a verse (Sabab an-Nuzul) or the origin of a hadith (Sabab wurud al-Hadith).
3 **Interpretation (Ta'wil):** Different but valid interpretations of the texts leading to different legal opinions (Madhahib/schools of law).
4 **Specification (Takhesis):** A general verse or hadith is restricted by a more specific verse or hadith.
5 **Prioritization:** Where hadiths appear to be contradictory, criteria are applied to determine the more authentic or relevant one.
6 **Harmonization (Jam'):** An attempt to understand seemingly contradictory texts in such a way that they are compatible with each other.

With this preliminary remark in mind, here are some examples of points that may be perceived as *apparent* contradictions or that lead to different legal interpretations:

1. **Punishments for adultery (zina):**
    ** **Apparent contradiction:** The Qur'an (Surah An-Nur 24:2) prescribes a punishment of 100 lashes for fornication (Zina). However, authentic hadiths (Sunnah) speak of the death penalty by stoning (Rajn) for *married* persons who commit adultery.
    **Explanation by scholarship:** Most scholars explain this by *naskh* (abrogation). They argue that the Quranic verse on lashing was an earlier revelation and was abrogated (abrogated) by the Sunnah (as also a divinely inspired source) in relation to married persons committing adultery, with the lash punishment still applying to unmarried persons. Another explanation is that the Quranic verse on stoning originally existed but was abrogated in the recitation (no longer in the Quran), but its legal effect (hukm) remained.
2 **Inheritance law:**
    * **Apparent contradiction/discussion:** The general rules in the Quran (e.g. Surah An-Nisa 4:11) state that sons usually inherit twice as much as daughters. However, there are specific hadiths or interpretations that may lead to different distributions in certain constellations or raise discussions about the fairness of this rule in the modern context, especially when it comes to the comparison of responsibilities (sons are traditionally responsible for the upkeep of the family).
    **Explanation by scholarship:** The 2:1 rule is considered the default case and is often justified by the fact that historically the man bore the financial burden of the family and the woman was free to dispose of her inheritance without incurring obligations to others (husband, children). Other parts of inheritance in the Qur'an and Sunnah (e.g. fixed shares for spouses, parents) complicate the picture and require complex calculations that do not always appear consistent at first glance, but are governed by precise legal rules.
3 **Purity after touching a woman:**
    * **Apparent contradiction/different interpretation:** The Qur'an (Sura An-Nisa 4:43, An-Ma'ida 5:6) speaks of repeating the ablution (wudu) when "touching women" (lamastum/lamastum an-nisa').
    **Explanation by the scholars:** The different schools of law interpret the word "touched" differently:
        *The Hanafi school interprets it as metaphorical for sexual contact (intercourse). Simple touching does not cancel ablution.
        * The Shafi'i school interprets it as literal touching (even unintentional, without lust) between a man and a woman (not related) that cancels ablution.
        * Other schools (Maliki, Hanbali) have nuances that take into account, for example, the intention or the presence of lust.
        This is a classic example of how different *interpretations* of the same Quranic word lead to different legal rules.
4 **Alcohol (intoxicants):**
    * **Apparent contradiction (historical):** Earlier verses in the Qur'an (e.g. Surah An-Nahl 16:67) mentioned wine (and dates) as a source of nourishment *and* intoxication without stating an explicit prohibition, while later verses (Surah Al-Baqara 2:219, An-Nisa 4:43) emphasized the negative aspects or prohibited prayer while intoxicated before finally stating a clear prohibition (Surah Al-Ma'ida 5:90).
    **Explanation by scholarship:** This is a clear example of *Naskh*. The legislation on alcohol evolved gradually, which is understood as a wise method of legislation to gradually wean the community away from an ingrained habit. The earlier verses were abrogated by the later, clear prohibitions.
5 **The role of music and images:**
    * **Apparent contradiction/different hadiths:** There are hadiths that seem to permit the playing of certain musical instruments (e.g. the daf at weddings or festivals) or the making of images/statues, while other hadiths are very strictly positioned against this and condemn it.
    **Explanation by scholarship:** Scholars have different views on this. They apply criteria of hadith authenticity, attempt to harmonize the hadiths (e.g. distinguish between permissible/impermissible music according to content or instrumentation; between prohibited depictions of living beings with shadows and permissible depictions without shadows/non-worshipful purposes), or prioritize certain hadiths over others. This leads to considerable differences of opinion among Muslims and scholars about the permissibility of music, images, photography, etc.

These examples show that what may appear to be a "contradiction" is usually dealt with and explained in the Islamic legal tradition through differentiated methods of interpretation, consideration of the historical context and the principle of abrogation. The diversity of the resulting opinions (the schools of law) is often seen not as a sign of error in the sources, but as a richness and expression of human endeavor to understand the divine will and implement it in life.

Statement_English: Give me examples of contradictions in Islamic law.
Statement_Language: Dê-me exemplos de contradições na lei islâmica.
Reply:
Responder a afirmações sobre contradições na lei islâmica (Sharia) é um tópico complexo, pois a perceção de "contradição" muitas vezes depende da perspetiva, do nível de conhecimento sobre os princípios legais islâmicos e das metodologias de interpretação utilizadas.

De uma perspetiva islâmica tradicional, a ideia de contradições fundamentais dentro do Alcorão ou da Suna (ditos e ações do Profeta Muhammad, que são as fontes primárias da Sharia) é geralmente rejeitada. Quaisquer aparentes inconsistências são explicadas através de:

1.  **Naskh (Abrogação):** Versículos ou hadith posteriores podem ter revogado ou modificado regras anteriores, refletindo uma revelação gradual ou adaptação a circunstâncias em mudança.
2.  **Contexto:** Textos diferentes podem aplicar-se a situações ou grupos de pessoas diferentes (por exemplo, tempo de guerra vs. tempo de paz, muçulmanos vs. não-muçulmanos, circunstâncias específicas).
3.  **Interpretação (Tafsir e Fiqh):** As diferentes escolas de pensamento legal (Madhabs) e os estudiosos individuais podem interpretar os textos de forma diferente com base em princípios jurídicos estabelecidos (como Ijma - consenso, Qiyas - analogia, Ijtihad - raciocínio independente), levando a regras diferentes que não são vistas como contradições, mas como diferentes caminhos válidos para entender a lei divina.
4.  **General vs. Specific:** Um texto geral pode ser qualificado por um texto mais específico.

No entanto, de uma perspetiva externa ou mesmo dentro de debates académicos e reformistas no mundo muçulmano, podem ser apontados exemplos de aparentes tensões ou áreas onde diferentes textos ou interpretações parecem colidir ou ser difíceis de reconciliar na prática moderna.

Aqui estão alguns exemplos de áreas onde *percebidas* "contradições" ou, mais precisamente, *tensões* e *diferenças de interpretação* são frequentemente discutidas:

1.  **Abrogação (Naskh) vs. Não-Abrogação:**
    *   **Exemplo:** Existem versículos no Alcorão que parecem mais tolerantes em relação aos não-muçulmanos e outros que soam mais conflituosos. A interpretação tradicional frequentemente aplica o princípio do Naskh, argumentando que versículos posteriores, revelados em tempos de conflito, abrogaram (substituíram) os versículos anteriores, revelados em Meca, mais pacíficos.
    *   **Alegada Tensão/Contradição:** Críticos e alguns estudiosos reformistas argumentam que o conceito de Naskh, especialmente em relação a versículos pacificadores, pode ser usado para justificar interpretações menos tolerantes e que todos os versículos devem ser considerados válidos e aplicados em contextos apropriados, sem que uns anulem os outros. A "contradição" estaria na existência de comandos aparentemente opostos que exigem uma explicação (como Naskh) para serem harmonizados.

2.  **Leis Penais (Hudud) vs. Misericórdia e Prova:**
    *   **Exemplo:** A Sharia prescreve punições severas (Hudud) para certos crimes (roubo, adultério, consumo de álcool). No entanto, os requisitos de prova para aplicar estas punições são extremamente rigorosos (por exemplo, quatro testemunhas oculares para adultério), e há uma forte ênfase na misericórdia, no arrependimento e em evitar a aplicação do Hudud sempre que possível (regra de "afastar o Hudud por qualquer dúvida").
    *   **Alegada Tensão/Contradição:** A tensão reside entre a prescrição textual de punições severas e as condições práticas e o espírito de misericórdia que tornam a sua aplicação rara e difícil. Para alguns, a contradição é que a lei parece ser dura no texto, mas difícil de implementar na prática, ou que a ênfase na misericórdia e no perdão parece estar em tensão com a ideia de punição divina fixa.

3.  **Estatuto e Direitos das Mulheres:**
    *   **Exemplo:** Existem textos que, quando interpretados literalmente por algumas escolas, parecem dar menos direitos às mulheres em áreas como herança (metade da parte de um homem), testemunho legal (o testemunho de duas mulheres igual ao de um homem em certos casos) ou autonomia (conceitos de tutela masculina - Qawamah). Por outro lado, existem outros textos e exemplos históricos que enfatizam a igualdade espiritual das mulheres, o seu direito à educação, ao trabalho, à propriedade e à participação na vida pública.
    *   **Alegada Tensão/Contradição:** A "contradição" não é tanto nos textos em si (que são interpretados de formas variadas), mas na forma como diferentes textos e princípios são priorizados ou reconciliados pelas várias escolas de pensamento, levando a aplicações muito diferentes da Sharia em relação às mulheres ao longo da história e em diferentes sociedades. O debate moderno frequentemente questiona se as interpretações tradicionais refletem fielmente o espírito de justiça e igualdade do Islão.

4.  **Tratamento de Não-Muçulmanos:**
    *   **Exemplo:** Existem versículos que promovem a coexistência pacífica, a justiça para com aqueles que não combatem os muçulmanos e o respeito pelos "Povos do Livro" (cristãos e judeus). Simultaneamente, existem textos que são interpretados como comandos para lutar contra os não-muçulmanos ou que estabelecem um estatuto legal inferior (dhimmi) para minorias religiosas em estados islâmicos tradicionais.
    *   **Alegada Tensão/Contradição:** Tal como no ponto 1, a tensão é frequentemente explicada pelo contexto (guerra vs. paz, diferentes tipos de não-muçulmanos - inimigos vs. súditos/cidadãos) ou por interpretações diferentes. A "contradição" é percebida por aqueles que veem dificuldade em reconciliar os textos que promovem a tolerância e a paz com aqueles que parecem comandar o conflito ou a subordinação.

5.  **Proibição de Juros (Riba) na Banca Moderna:**
    *   **Exemplo:** O Alcorão proíbe explicitamente o Riba, que é geralmente interpretado como juros ou usura. No entanto, a aplicação literal desta proibição no sistema financeiro global moderno, baseado em juros, é extremamente desafiadora. Isto levou ao desenvolvimento da banca islâmica, que tenta estruturar transações financeiras de forma a evitar o juro direto, utilizando métodos como partilha de lucros/perdas, taxas de serviço ou aluguer (Murabaha, Musharaka, Ijarah, etc.).
    *   **Alegada Tensão/Contradição:** Críticos argumentam que algumas destas estruturas financeiras islâmicas são meras manobras legais (hilah) que contornam a proibição do Riba no espírito, mesmo que a evitem na letra. A "contradição" seria entre a proibição clara de juros e a necessidade prática de participar numa economia baseada em juros, levando a soluções que alguns veem como inconsistentes com a intenção original da lei.

**Conclusão:**

Ao abordar "contradições" na lei islâmica, é essencial entender que o que um crítico pode ver como uma falha lógica ou inconsistência, um jurista islâmico tradicional verá como diferentes facetas de uma lei complexa e dinâmica, aplicável a diversas situações e sujeita a metodologias de interpretação rigorosas. As aparentes contradições são, na maioria das vezes, áreas de debate académico, diferenças de interpretação, ou questões que surgem da tentativa de aplicar textos antigos a realidades modernas e complexas. A Sharia, como qualquer sistema legal abrangente baseado em textos e tradições, é vasta, multifacetada e sujeita a uma rica história de interpretação e desenvolvimento.

EnglishTranslation:
Responding to claims about contradictions in Islamic law (Sharia) is a complex topic, as the perception of "contradiction" often depends on the perspective, the level of knowledge about Islamic legal principles and the methodologies of interpretation used.

From a traditional Islamic perspective, the idea of fundamental contradictions within the Qur'an or the Sunnah (sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad, which are the primary sources of Sharia) is generally rejected. Any apparent inconsistencies are explained through:

1.  **Naskh (Abrogation):** Later verses or hadith may have abrogated or modified earlier rules, reflecting a gradual revelation or adaptation to changing circumstances.
2.  **Context:** Different texts may apply to different situations or groups of people (e.g. wartime vs. peacetime, Muslims vs. non-Muslims, specific circumstances).
3.  **Interpretation (Tafsir and Fiqh):** Different schools of legal thought (Madhabs) and individual scholars may interpret texts differently based on established legal principles (such as Ijma - consensus, Qiyas - analogy, Ijtihad - independent reasoning), leading to different rules that are not seen as contradictions, but as different valid ways of understanding divine law.
4.  **General vs. Specific:** A general text can be qualified by a more specific text.

However, from an external perspective or even within academic and reformist debates in the Muslim world, examples can be pointed to of apparent tensions or areas where different texts or interpretations seem to clash or be difficult to reconcile in modern practice.

Here are some examples of areas where *perceived* "contradictions" or, more precisely, *tensions* and *differences of interpretation* are often discussed:

1.  **Abrogation (Naskh) vs. Non-Abrogation.
    * There are verses in the Qur'an that sound more tolerant towards non-Muslims and others that sound more confrontational. Traditional interpretation often applies the principle of Naskh, arguing that later verses, revealed in times of conflict, abrogated (replaced) the earlier, more peaceful verses revealed in Mecca.
    * Critics and some reformist scholars argue that the concept of Naskh, especially in relation to peacemaking verses, can be used to justify less tolerant interpretations and that all verses should be considered valid and applied in appropriate contexts, without one canceling out the other. The "contradiction" would be in the existence of apparently opposing commands that require an explanation (such as Naskh) in order to be harmonized.

2.  **Penal Laws (Hudud) vs. Mercy and Proof:**
    **Example:** Sharia prescribes severe punishments (Hudud) for certain crimes (theft, adultery, alcohol consumption). However, the proof requirements for applying these punishments are extremely strict (e.g. four eyewitnesses for adultery), and there is a strong emphasis on mercy, repentance and avoiding the application of Hudud whenever possible (the rule of "ward off Hudud for any doubt").
    * The tension lies between the textual prescription of severe punishments and the practical conditions and spirit of mercy that make their application rare and difficult. For some, the contradiction is that the law seems harsh in the text but difficult to implement in practice, or that the emphasis on mercy and forgiveness seems to be in tension with the idea of fixed divine punishment.

3.  **Women's Statute and Rights:**
    * There are texts which, when interpreted literally by some schools, seem to give women fewer rights in areas such as inheritance (half of a man's share), legal testimony (the testimony of two women equal to that of a man in certain cases) or autonomy (concepts of male guardianship - Qawamah). On the other hand, there are other texts and historical examples that emphasize the spiritual equality of women, their right to education, work, property and participation in public life.
    * The "contradiction" is not so much in the texts themselves (which are interpreted in a variety of ways), but in the way different texts and principles are prioritized or reconciled by the various schools of thought, leading to very different applications of Sharia in relation to women throughout history and in different societies. Modern debate often questions whether traditional interpretations faithfully reflect Islam's spirit of justice and equality.

4.  **Treatment of Non-Muslims:**
    * There are verses that promote peaceful coexistence, justice for those who do not fight Muslims and respect for the "People of the Book" (Christians and Jews). At the same time, there are texts that are interpreted as commands to fight non-Muslims or that establish an inferior legal status (dhimmi) for religious minorities in traditional Islamic states.
    * As in point 1, tension is often explained by context (war vs. peace, different types of non-Muslims - enemies vs. subjects/citizens) or by different interpretations. The "contradiction" is perceived by those who see difficulty in reconciling texts that promote tolerance and peace with those that seem to command conflict or subordination.

5.  **Prohibition of Interest (Riba) in Modern Banking:**
    * The Qur'an explicitly forbids Riba, which is generally interpreted as interest or usury. However, the literal application of this prohibition in the modern interest-based global financial system is extremely challenging. This has led to the development of Islamic banking, which attempts to structure financial transactions in a way that avoids direct interest, using methods such as profit/loss sharing, service fees or rent (Murabaha, Musharaka, Ijarah, etc.).
    * Critics argue that some of these Islamic financial structures are merely legal maneuvers (hilah) that circumvent the prohibition of Riba in spirit, even if they avoid it in letter. The "contradiction" would be between the clear prohibition of interest and the practical need to participate in an interest-based economy, leading to solutions that some see as inconsistent with the original intent of the law.

**Conclusion

When addressing "contradictions" in Islamic law, it is essential to understand that what a critic might see as a logical flaw or inconsistency, a traditional Islamic jurist will see as different facets of a complex and dynamic law, applicable to diverse situations and subject to strict methodologies of interpretation. The apparent contradictions are most often areas of academic debate, differences of interpretation, or issues that arise from trying to apply ancient texts to modern and complex realities. Sharia, like any comprehensive legal system based on texts and traditions, is vast, multifaceted and subject to a rich history of interpretation and development.

Statement_English: Give me examples of contradictions in Islamic law.
Statement_Language: Приведите мне примеры противоречий в исламском праве.
Reply:
Как эксперт, подходя к вопросу о "противоречиях" в исламском праве, важно сначала определить, что имеется в виду под этим термином в данном контексте. В классической исламской юриспруденции (фикх) и теологии (акыда) считается, что первичные источники права – Коран и Сунна (жизненный путь Пророка Мухаммада) – по своей сути не содержат противоречий, поскольку являются божественным откровением.

Однако, на практике и в процессе развития исламского права, возникают ситуации, которые могут *казаться* противоречивыми или приводить к различным правовым заключениям (фетвам). Это происходит по нескольким причинам:

1.  **Различная интерпретация текстов:** Один и тот же аят Корана или хадис (предание о словах или действиях Пророка) может быть истолкован разными учеными по-разному.
2.  **Разная степень достоверности хадисов:** Существуют хадисы разной степени надежности, и ученые могут иметь разные мнения относительно их достоверности, что влияет на принимаемые на их основе решения.
3.  **Контекст:** Тексты могут относиться к разным историческим или ситуационным контекстам.
4.  **Применение юридических принципов:** Ученые используют различные методологии (усуль аль-фикх), такие как кыяс (аналогия), истихсан (предпочтение), истислах (учет общественной пользы), что может приводить к разным результатам.
5.  **Отмена (Насх):** В исламском праве признается концепция "насх", когда более позднее откровение или Сунна отменяет (заменяет) более раннее по тому же вопросу. Это не противоречие, а последовательное законодательство в рамках божественного плана, но может выглядеть как конфликт, если не знать о порядке ниспослания.
6.  **Различия между правовыми школами (Мазхабы):** Суннитский ислам исторически развил несколько основных правовых школ (ханафитская, маликитская, шафиитская, ханбалитская), которые имеют свои методологии и часто приходят к разным заключениям по одним и тем же вопросам, основанным на разных интерпретациях или предпочтении разных доказательств. Эти различия внутри границ общепринятых методик, как правило, считаются легитимным "ихтиляфом" (разногласием мнений).

Примеры ситуаций, которые могут *выглядеть* как противоречия или приводят к разным правовым заключениям (не являясь "противоречиями" в смысле ошибок в источнике с точки зрения классической юриспруденции):

1.  **Вопрос о нарушении омовения (вуду) при касании женщины:**
    *   **Аргумент 1:** Некоторые ученые (например, в шафиитской школе) считают, что простое касание кожи противоположного пола, не являющегося близким родственником (махрамом), нарушает омовение, основываясь на буквальном толковании аята 4:43 из Корана ("...или прикасались к женщинам...") и некоторых хадисах.
    *   **Аргумент 2:** Другие ученые (например, в ханафитской школе) считают, что омовение нарушается только при касании с вожделением, или что аят 4:43 следует толковать как метафору полового акта, основываясь на других хадисах, где Пророк целовал своих жен после совершения омовения.
    *   **Итог:** Это различие возникает из-за разной интерпретации одного и того же коранического термина ("ллямастум ан-ниса") и предпочтения разных хадисов или разных методологий их согласования.

2.  **Наследование для внуков при наличии сыновей:**
    *   **Ситуация:** Умирает человек. У него есть взрослый сын и внук от *другого*, умершего ранее, сына. По традиционным правилам наследования (основанным на аятах Корана), внук не наследует, потому что его "заслоняет" более близкий наследник (дядя).
    *   **Якобы "противоречие":** Это может выглядеть несправедливым или противоречить общему духу ислама, который поощряет заботу о сиротах.
    *   **Разрешение/Различия:** Большинство классических школ придерживаются буквального толкования правил наследования из Корана. Однако, некоторые современные ученые и законодательства в ряде мусульманских стран (например, в Египте, Сирии, Марокко) ввели концепцию "обязательного завещания" (васия ваджиба), согласно которой внуки, чьи родители умерли раньше наследодателя, *автоматически* получают долю, равную той, что получил бы их родитель, если бы был жив, но не превышающую трети всего наследства. Это решение основано на принципе общественной пользы (масляха) и общем духе заботы о нуждающихся, *не отменяя* при этом прямые коранические правила наследования, а дополняя их через механизм завещания.

3.  **Употребление алкоголя:**
    *   **Ранние предписания:** Изначально в Коране были аяты, которые лишь не одобряли пьянство во время молитвы (4:43) или указывали на вред алкоголя, наряду с пользой (для торговли), но с большим вредом (2:219).
    *   **Окончательное предписание:** Позднее был ниспослан аят 5:90, который категорически запретил алкоголь ("вино, азартные игры... - мерзость из деяний шайтана").
    *   **Объяснение:** Это классический пример *насха* (отмены). Ранние аяты не были противоречием позднему, а представляли собой постепенное введение запрета, учитывающее привычки общества того времени.

4.  **Показания женщин в суде:**
    *   **Коран 2:282:** В контексте финансовых сделок говорится: "...и призовите двух свидетелей из числа ваших мужчин, а если не будет двух мужчин, то одного мужчину и двух женщин из тех, кого вы согласны признать свидетелями, чтобы, если одна из них забудет, другая напомнила ей...".
    *   **Якобы "противоречие" или несправедливость:** Этот аят часто цитируется как пример того, что показания женщины вдвое "слабее" показаний мужчины.
    *   **Разрешение/Контекст:** Ученые указывают, что этот аят относится *конкретно* к финансовым сделкам, где женщины в VII веке могли быть менее осведомлены и опытны, и цель двух женщин - взаимопомощь при вспоминании деталей. В других областях права (например, в семейных делах, или при свидетельстве о рождении, или даже при доказательстве преступлений, которые видела только женщина) показания женщины могут быть признаны наравне с мужскими или даже единственными допустимыми. Разные школы и ученые имеют разные мнения о применимости аята 2:282 к другим типам свидетельств, что опять же порождает различия в правовых заключениях.

Важно понимать, что наличие разных интерпретаций и правовых школ в исламе не рассматривается большинством мусульманских ученых как признак "противоречий" в самих источниках, а скорее как богатство и гибкость исламского права, позволяющая применять его в разных условиях и ситуациях, а также как естественный результат человеческих усилий по пониманию божественной воли. Различия в фикхе часто являются следствием применения различных, но легитимных методологий исследования и толкования текстов.

4.  **Показания женщин в суде:**
    *   **Коран 2:282:** В контексте финансовых сделок говорится: "...и призовите двух свидетелей из числа ваших мужчин, а если не будет двух мужчин, то одного мужчину и двух женщин из тех, кого вы согласны признать свидетелями, чтобы, если одна из них забудет, другая напомнила ей...".
    *   **Якобы "противоречие" или несправедливость:** Этот аят часто цитируется как пример того, что показания женщины вдвое "слабее" показаний мужчины.

Важно понимать, что наличие разных интерпретаций и правовых школ в исламе не рассматривается большинством мусульманских ученых как признак "противоречий" в самих источниках, а скорее как богатство и гибкость исламского права, позволяющая применять его в разных условиях и ситуациях, а также как естественный результат человеческих усилий по пониманию божественной воли. Различия в фикхе часто являются следствием применения различных, но легитимных методологий исследования и толкования текстов."}], "role": "model"}, "citation_metadata": null, "finish_message": null, "token_count": null, "finish_reason": "STOP", "avg_logprobs": null, "grounding_metadata": null, "index": 0, "logprobs_result": null, "safety_ratings": null}], "create_time": null, "response_id": null, "model_version": "models/gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17", "prompt_feedback": null, "usage_metadata": {"cache_tokens_details": null, "cached_content_token_count": null, "candidates_token_count": 1826, "candidates_tokens_details": null, "prompt_token_count": 38, "prompt_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 38}], "thoughts_token_count": 1147, "tool_use_prompt_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_tokens_details": null, "total_token_count": 3011, "traffic_type": null}, "automatic_function_calling_history": [], "parsed": null}
EnglishTranslation:
As an expert, when approaching the issue of "contradictions" in Islamic law, it is important to first define what is meant by this term in this context. In classical Islamic jurisprudence (fiqh) and theology (aqeedah), it is believed that the primary sources of law - the Qur'an and Sunnah (the life path of the Prophet Muhammad) - are inherently free of contradictions because they are divine revelation.

However, in practice and in the development of Islamic law, situations arise that may *appear* to be contradictory or lead to different legal conclusions (fatwas). This occurs for several reasons:

1.  **Different interpretations of texts:** The same ayat of the Qur'an or hadith (a tradition about the words or actions of the Prophet) may be interpreted differently by different scholars.
2.  ** Different degrees of reliability of hadiths:** There are hadiths of different degrees of reliability and scholars may have different opinions on their reliability, which affects the decisions based on them.
3.  **Context:** Texts may refer to different historical or situational contexts.
4.  **Application of legal principles:** Scholars use different methodologies (usul al-fiqh) such as qiyas (analogy), istihsan (preference), istislah (consideration of public benefit), which may lead to different results.
5.  **Nullification (Naskh):** Islamic law recognizes the concept of naskh, where a later revelation or Sunnah abrogates (replaces) an earlier one on the same issue. This is not a contradiction but a consistent legislation within the divine plan, but may look like a conflict if one is not aware of the order of naskh.
6.  **Differences between schools of law (Mazhabs):** Sunni Islam has historically developed several major schools of law (Hanafi, Maliki, Shafi'i, Hanbali) which have their own methodologies and often come to different conclusions on the same issues based on different interpretations or favoring different evidence. These differences within the boundaries of generally accepted methodologies are generally considered legitimate "ikhtilaf" (difference of opinion).

Examples of situations that may *look* like contradictions or lead to different legal conclusions (without being "contradictions" in the sense of errors in the source from the perspective of classical jurisprudence):

1.  **The question of the violation of ablution (voodoo) by touching a woman:**
    * **Argument 1:** Some scholars (e.g. in the Shafi'i school) believe that mere touching the skin of the opposite sex who is not a close relative (mahram) violates ablution, based on the literal interpretation of Ayat 4:43 from the Qur'an ("...or touching women...") and some hadiths.
    * **Argument 2:** Other scholars (e.g. in the Hanafi school) believe that ablution is only violated by touching with lust, or that Ayat 4:43 should be interpreted as a metaphor for sexual intercourse, based on other hadiths where the Prophet kissed his wives after performing ablution.
    * **Summary:** This difference arises due to different interpretations of the same Qur'anic term ('llamastum an-nisa) and the preference for different hadiths or different methodologies for reconciling them.

2.  **Inheritance for grandchildren in the presence of sons:**
    * ** **Situation:** A man dies. He has an adult son and a grandson from *another* son who died earlier. According to traditional rules of inheritance (based on ayats of the Quran), the grandson does not inherit because he is "overshadowed" by a closer heir (uncle).
    * **An alleged "contradiction":** This may seem unfair or contrary to the general spirit of Islam, which encourages the care of orphans.
    * **Resolution/Differences:** Most classical schools adhere to a literal interpretation of the rules of inheritance from the Qur'an. However, some modern scholars and legislation in a number of Muslim countries (e.g., Egypt, Syria, Morocco) have introduced the concept of "compulsory bequest" (wasiya wajiba), according to which grandchildren whose parents died before the testator *automatically* receive a share equal to what their parent would have received had he or she been alive, but not exceeding one-third of the entire inheritance. This solution is based on the principle of public benefit (maslaha) and the general spirit of caring for the needy, *without abrogating* the direct Qur'anic rules of inheritance, but rather supplementing them through the mechanism of the will.

3.  **Consumption of alcohol:**
    * **Early injunctions:**The Qur'an originally had ayats that merely disapproved of drinking during prayer (4:43) or pointed out the harms of alcohol, along with benefits (for trade) but with greater harms (2:219).
    * **Final injunction:** Later, Ayat 5:90 was sent down which categorically forbade alcohol ("wine, gambling... is an abomination from the deeds of Shaitan").
    * ** **Explanation:** This is a classic example of *nasah* (abrogation). The earlier ayat was not a contradiction to the later one, but was a gradual introduction of prohibition, taking into account the habits of the society of the time.

4.  **The testimony of women in court:**
    * **Qur'an 2:282:** In the context of financial transactions it says: "...and call two witnesses from among your men, and if there are not two men, then one man and two women from among those whom you agree to recognize as witnesses, so that if one of them forgets, the other shall remind her...".
    * **An "contradiction" or injustice:** This ayat is often quoted as an example of a woman's testimony being twice as "weak" as a man's.
    * **Resolution/Context:** Scholars indicate that this ayat refers *specifically* to financial transactions, where women in the 7th century may have been less knowledgeable and experienced, and the purpose of the two women is mutual aid in recalling details. In other areas of law (such as in family matters, or birth certificates, or even in proving crimes that only a woman saw), a woman's testimony may be considered on par with a man's, or even the only admissible testimony. Different schools and scholars have different views on the applicability of Ayat 2:282 to other types of testimony, which again gives rise to differences in legal conclusions.

It is important to realize that the existence of different interpretations and legal schools in Islam is not seen by most Muslim scholars as a sign of "contradictions" in the sources themselves, but rather as a richness and flexibility of Islamic law that allows it to be applied in different contexts and situations, and as a natural result of human efforts to understand the divine will. Differences in fiqh are often the result of different but legitimate methodologies of research and interpretation of texts.

Statement_English: Give me examples of contradictions in Islamic law.
Statement_Language: मुझे इस्लामी कानून में विरोधाभासों के उदाहरण दें।
Reply:
जी हाँ, मैं आपके बयान पर जानकारी देने का प्रयास करता हूँ।

इस्लामी कानून (शरिया) एक बहुत विशाल और जटिल व्यवस्था है जो कुरान, हदीस (पैगंबर मुहम्मद की बातें और कार्य), इज्मा (विद्वानों की सहमति) और क़ियास (तुलनात्मक तर्क) पर आधारित है। इसमें सीधे तौर पर 'विरोधाभास' कहना अक्सर मुश्किल होता है, क्योंकि इस्लामी विद्वान जिन बिंदुओं को बाहरी तौर पर विरोधाभासी देख सकते हैं, वे अक्सर गहन व्याख्या, संदर्भ, इतिहास या विभिन्न विचारधाराओं (मज़हबों) के दृष्टिकोण से समझाए जाते हैं।

इस्लामी विद्वता में, '**नस्ख**' (abrogation - यानी एक बाद के रहस्योद्घाटन या हदीस द्वारा पहले वाले को रद्द करना) और **विभिन्न मज़हबों** (कानूनी विचारधाराओं, जैसे हनफी, मालिकी, शाफी'ई, हंबली) की अलग-अलग व्याख्याएं ऐसे 'विरोधाभास' दिखने वाले बिंदुओं को समझने के लिए महत्वपूर्ण हैं।

फिर भी, कुछ ऐसे बिंदु हैं जिन पर अक्सर चर्चा होती है और जो विभिन्न व्याख्याओं या ऐतिहासिक विकास के कारण भिन्न प्रतीत हो सकते हैं। इन्हें अक्सर विरोधाभास के बजाय **विभिन्न दृष्टिकोणों या व्याख्याओं के उदाहरण** के रूप में देखा जाता है:

1.  **मनसूख आयतें (Abrogated Verses):** कुरान में कुछ ऐसे छंद हैं जिनके नियम शुरुआती चरणों में दिए गए थे और बाद में उन्हें अन्य छंदों द्वारा मनसूख (रद्द या संशोधित) कर दिया गया। उदाहरण के लिए, शराब पीने के संबंध में शुरुआती नियम धीरे-धीरे सख्त हुए जब तक कि इसे पूरी तरह से हराम घोषित नहीं कर दिया गया। कुछ लोग शुरुआती और बाद के छंदों को एक साथ देखने पर विरोधाभास देख सकते हैं, लेकिन इस्लामी विद्वान इसे अल्लाह के निर्देशों के क्रमिक विकास और मनसूख के सिद्धांत से समझाते हैं।

2.  **विभिन्न कानूनी मज़हबों की राय में अंतर:** विभिन्न कानूनी विचारधाराओं (मज़हबों) के विद्वान कुरान और हदीस की व्याख्या करने के लिए अलग-अलग तरीकों का उपयोग करते हैं, जिससे कुछ विशिष्ट मुद्दों पर उनकी कानूनी राय (फ़िक़्ह) में अंतर आ सकता है। उदाहरण के लिए:
    *   क्या किसी खास प्रकार का वित्तीय लेनदेन हलाल है या हराम (ब्याज - रिबा - से जुड़ा मामला)?
    *   प्रार्थना के दौरान हाथों को कैसे रखा जाए?
    *   महिलाओं की गवाही या विरासत का अनुपात कुछ विशिष्ट संदर्भों में।
    *   विभिन्न प्रकार की अशुद्धता (नजासा) और उन्हें शुद्ध करने के तरीके।
    ये अंतर अक्सर कुरान की आयतों या हदीसों की अलग-अलग व्याख्याओं, उनकी प्रामाणिकता के स्तर या उन्हें लागू करने के तरीके पर आधारित होते हैं, न कि सीधे विरोधाभासों पर।

3.  **संदर्भ-आधारित नियम:** कुछ नियम किसी विशिष्ट ऐतिहासिक संदर्भ या परिस्थिति के लिए थे। उन्हें बिना संदर्भ के पढ़ने पर वे अन्य सामान्य नियमों से भिन्न या विरोधाभासी लग सकते हैं।

इसलिए, जिन्हें कुछ लोग विरोधाभास मान सकते हैं, उन्हें इस्लामी विद्वान अक्सर व्याख्यात्मक विविधता, संदर्भ, मनसूख के सिद्धांत या ऐतिहासिक विकास के हिस्से के रूप में देखते हैं। इन बिंदुओं पर सदियों से विद्वानों के बीच बहसें और चर्चाएं होती रही हैं।

EnglishTranslation:
Yes, I try to give information on your statement. Islamic law (Sharia) is a very vast and complex system based on Quran, Hadith (Prophet Muhammad's words and work), Ijma (consent of scholars) and Qias (comparative argument). It is often difficult to say 'contradiction' directly, because the points that the Islamic scholars can see externally can see the contradictory are often explained from the perspective of intensive interpretation, reference, history or various ideologies (religion). In Islamic scholarship, different interpretations of '** nusk **' (ie abrogation - ie a subsequent revelation or cancellation of the first by Hadith) and ** Different religion ** (legal ideologies, such as Hanfi, Maliki, Shafi, Hambli) are important to understand such 'contradictory' looking points. Nevertheless, there are some points that are often discussed and may appear to be different due to different interpretations or historical development. They are often seen as examples of various approaches or interpretations ** instead of contradiction:

1. ** Abrogated Verses: ** There are some verses in the Quran whose rules were given in the initial stages and later they were made (canceled or modified) by other verses. For example, the initial rules regarding drinking alcohol gradually became strict until it was declared completely forbidden. Some people may see the contradiction when looking at the early and subsequent verses together, but the Islamic scholars explain it to the principle of gradual development and mansukh of Allah. 2. ** Difference in opinion of different legal religion: ** Scholars of various legal ideologies (religion) use different ways to explain the Quran and Hadith, which may make a difference in their legal opinion (fich) on certain issues. For example:
    * Is there a particular type of financial transaction halal or haram (case related to interest - riba)? * How to keep hands during prayer? * Women's testimony or heritage ratio in some specific contexts. * Different types of impurities (najasa) and ways to clean them. These differences are often based on different interpretations of the verses of the Quran, or the way of their authenticity, or how to apply them, not on direct contradictions. 3. ** Reference-based rules: ** Some rules were for a specific historical reference or situation. They may seem different or contradictory from other general rules when reading them without reference. Therefore, some people who can consider contradictions, Islamic scholars often see them as part of explanatory diversity, reference, principle of mans and historical development. There have been debates and discussions between scholars for centuries on these points.

Statement_English: Give me examples of contradictions in Islamic law.
Statement_Language: Bana İslam hukukundaki çelişkilerden örnekler verin.
Reply:
İslam hukukunda (Şeriat), tam anlamıyla birbiriyle çelişen iki ayetin veya hadisin aynı anda geçerli olması kabul edilmez. İslam alimleri, Kur'an ve Sünnet'in birbiriyle uyumlu olduğunu ve görünen çelişkilerin genellikle farklı bağlamlardan, nesh (hükmün kaldırılması) ilkesinden veya yorum farklılıklarından kaynaklandığını belirtirler.

Ancak, "çelişki" olarak algılanabilecek veya farklı yorumlara yol açan bazı durumlar ve konular mevcuttur. Bunlar daha çok, metinlerin yorumlanması, farklı metinlerin uzlaştırılması veya uygulamanın bağlama göre değişmesiyle ilgilidir. İşte bu tür durumlara bazı örnekler:

1.  **Nesh (Hükmün Kaldırılması):** İslam hukukunda, sonraki bir vahyin (ayet veya hadis) daha önceki bir vahyin hükmünü kaldırması veya değiştirmesi ilkesi (Nesh) bulunur. Bu, özellikle İslam'ın ilk dönemlerinde, toplumun aşamalı olarak yeni kurallara alıştırılması sürecinde kullanılmıştır. Örneğin, içki ile ilgili ayetlerin aşamalı olarak indirilmesi ve en sonunda kesin olarak haram kılınması bu duruma örnektir. Tek tek ayetlere bakıldığında farklı hükümler varmış gibi görünse de, nesh ilkesi bu durumu izah eder. *Bu, "çelişki" değil, hukukun zaman içinde tedricen şekillenmesidir.*

2.  **Farklı Yorum ve İçtihatlar (Mezhepler Arası Farklılıklar):** Kur'an ve Sünnet metinlerinin anlaşılması ve güncel sorunlara uygulanması konusunda farklı metodolojiler ve yorumlar ortaya çıkmıştır. Farklı mezhepler (Hanefi, Maliki, Şafii, Hanbeli vb.) aynı metinlerden farklı sonuçlar çıkarabilir.
    *   **Örnek:** Kadınların şahitliği konusunda farklı görüşler. Bazı mezhepler belirli konularda iki kadının şahitliğini bir erkeğin şahitliğine denk tutan hadisleri temel alırken, diğerleri genel şahitlik ilkesini veya bağlamı farklı yorumlayabilir.
    *   **Örnek:** Abdest veya gusülde bazı detayların farz mı, sünnet mi olduğu konusundaki farklılıklar.
    *   *Bu, ilahi kaynağın kendisindeki bir çelişki değil, beşeri yorumlama (içtihat) sürecinden kaynaklanan farklılıklardır.*

3.  **Genel Prensipler ve İstisnai Durumlar:** Bazen genel bir kural veya prensiple, belirli bir durumu ele alan özel bir hüküm arasında bir gerilim olabilir. Hukukçular, bu tür durumları uzlaştırmak için özel hükmün istisna teşkil ettiğini veya genel prensibin uygulama alanını daralttığını belirtirler.
    *   **Örnek:** Hırsızlık cezasının (el kesme) prensibi olmasına rağmen, açlık veya aşırı yoksulluk gibi durumlarda bu cezanın uygulanıp uygulanmayacağı veya nasıl yorumlanacağı konusunda tartışmaların olması. Genel ilke "hırsızlık cezalandırılır" olsa da, istisnai insani durumlar veya delil yetersizliği gibi faktörler uygulamanın farklılaşmasına yol açabilir.

4.  **Ayet ve Hadislerin Bağlamı:** Bazı ayetler veya hadisler, indikleri veya söylendikleri belirli bir tarihi, sosyal veya hukuki bağlama sahiptir. Bu bağlamdan koparılarak okunduğunda, başka bir metinle çelişiyor gibi görünebilir.
    *   **Örnek:** Savaşla ilgili ayetler. Bazı ayetler savaşta sertliği vurgularken, diğerleri barışı, affetmeyi ve antlaşmalara uymayı emreder. Bunlar farklı savaş durumları, düşmanın tutumu veya antlaşmaların varlığı gibi farklı bağlamlara işaret eder ve birbiriyle çelişmez, aksine savaş hukukunun farklı yönlerini gösterir.

5.  **Kadınların Statüsü İle İlgili Tartışmalar:** Miras, şahitlik, giyim gibi konulardaki farklı metinler ve bu metinlerin günümüz koşullarında nasıl yorumlanması gerektiği konusundaki tartışmalar, bu alanda "çelişki" veya "adil olmayan hükümler" gibi algılara yol açabilmektedir. Farklı ayet ve hadislerin nasıl uzlaştırıldığı ve farklı mezheplerin bu konuları nasıl ele aldığı, bu alandaki tartışmaların odağındadır.

Sonuç olarak, İslam hukukunda "çelişki" olarak algılanan durumlar genellikle ilahi kaynakların (Kur'an ve Sünnet) kendisinden ziyade, bu kaynakların farklı zamanlardaki iniş/söylenme bağlamlarından (nesh), alimlerin bu metinleri anlama ve yorumlama metodolojilerindeki (içtihat/mezhepler) farklılıklardan veya metinlerin dar anlamıyla, bağlamından koparılarak okunmasından kaynaklanır. İslam hukuk geleneği, bu tür görünen farklılıkları uzlaştırmak ve hukuka tutarlılık kazandırmak için karmaşık ve sofistike usul (metodoloji) ilimleri geliştirmiştir.

EnglishTranslation:
Islamic law (Shari'ah) does not recognize the simultaneous validity of two literally contradictory verses or hadiths. Islamic scholars state that the Qur'an and Sunnah are in harmony with each other and that apparent contradictions are usually due to different contexts, the principle of neshah (abrogation) or differences in interpretation.

However, there are some situations and issues that may be perceived as "contradictions" or lead to different interpretations. These are mostly related to the interpretation of texts, the reconciliation of different texts or the contextualization of practice. Here are some examples of such situations:

1. **Nesh (Abrogation of Ruling):** In Islamic law, there is the principle of Nesh (abrogation) whereby a later revelation (verse or hadith) abrogates or modifies the ruling of an earlier revelation. This was used especially in the early period of Islam in the process of gradually acclimatizing the society to the new rules. For example, the gradual revelation of the verses on drinking and the eventual definitive forbidding of it. The principle of neshah explains this, even though the individual verses may appear to have different provisions. *This is not a "contradiction" but the gradual shaping of law over time.

2. **Different Interpretations and Ijtihad (Inter-Sectarian Differences):** Different methodologies and interpretations have emerged in understanding the Qur'an and Sunnah texts and applying them to contemporary problems. Different sects (Hanafi, Maliki, Shafi'i, Hanbali, etc.) may draw different conclusions from the same texts.
    * **Example:** Different views on women's testimony. While some schools of thought may rely on hadiths that equate the testimony of two women to the testimony of one man in certain matters, others may interpret the general principle of testimony or the context differently.
    * **Example:** Differences over whether certain details in ablution or ghusl are obligatory or sunnah.
    * This is not a contradiction in the divine source itself, but differences arising from the process of human interpretation (ijtihad).

3. **General Principles and Exceptional Circumstances:** Sometimes there is a tension between a general rule or principle and a special provision addressing a particular situation. To reconcile such situations, jurists state that the special provision constitutes an exception or narrows the scope of application of the general principle.
    * **Example:** Although there is a general principle of punishment for theft (cutting off the hand), there are disputes about whether or how to apply or interpret this punishment in situations such as hunger or extreme poverty. While the general principle is that "theft is punishable", factors such as exceptional humanitarian circumstances or lack of evidence may lead to divergent practice.

4. **Context of Verses and Hadiths:** Some verses or hadiths have a specific historical, social or legal context in which they were revealed or said. When read out of this context, they may appear to contradict another text.
    * **Example:** Verses about war. Some verses emphasize harshness in war, while others command peace, forgiveness and keeping treaties. They refer to different contexts, such as different war situations, the attitude of the enemy or the existence of treaties, and do not contradict each other, but rather illustrate different aspects of the law of war.

5. **Discussions on the Status of Women:** Different texts on issues such as inheritance, testimony, clothing, etc. and discussions on how these texts should be interpreted in today's conditions can lead to perceptions such as "contradiction" or "unfair rulings" in this field. How different verses and hadiths are reconciled and how different sects deal with these issues are at the center of the debates in this field.

Consequently, what is perceived as a "contradiction" in Islamic law usually stems not from the divine sources (the Qur'an and Sunnah) themselves, but from the contexts in which these sources were revealed at different times (nesh), differences in the methodologies of scholars in understanding and interpreting these texts (ijtihad/sects), or the narrow, decontextualized reading of the texts. The Islamic legal tradition has developed complex and sophisticated sciences of usul (methodology) to reconcile such apparent differences and bring coherence to the law.

Statement_English: Give me examples of contradictions in Islamic law.
Statement_Language: Gee my voorbeelde van teenstrydighede in die Islamitiese reg.
Reply:
Dit is 'n geldige en interessante vraag, en as kenner van sulke stellings kan ek bevestig dat die idee van "teenstrydighede" in enige komplekse regsstelsel, veral een wat oor eeue ontwikkel het en op godsdienstige tekste gebaseer is, 'n punt van bespreking kan wees.

Dit is egter belangrik om te onderskei tussen ware, onoplosbare teenstrydighede en:

1.  **Verskille in Interpretasie:** Verskillende skole van Islamitiese reg (madhahib) en individuele geleerdes het verskillende maniere om die Koran en die Hadith (profetiese tradisies) te interpreteer en toe te pas. Dit lei tot uiteenlopende regerings oor dieselfde kwessies.
2.  **Skynbare Teenstrydighede wat Deur Regsmetodologie Opgelos Word:** Islamitiese regspraak (Usul al-Fiqh) het metodes ontwikkel om teksuele konflikte te hanteer, soos opheffing (naskh), harmonisering (jam' wa tawfiq), spesifisering (takhsis), en prioritisering (tarjih).
3.  **Kontekstuele Toepassing:** Sommige reëls mag slegs van toepassing wees in spesifieke omstandighede of historiese kontekste.

Wanneer mense praat van "teenstrydighede", verwys hulle dikwels na skynbare konflikpunte wat binne die Islamitiese regsraamwerk op verskillende maniere verklaar of versoen word. Hier is 'n paar areas waar sulke "teenstrydighede" (of eerder, punte van interpretatiewe verskil of debat) dikwels aangehaal word:

1.  **Verskillende Rulings tussen Regskole (Madhahib):** Die mees voor die hand liggende "teenstrydigheid" vir buitestaanders is die verskil in fiqh (Islamitiese regspraak) tussen die verskillende Sunni-skole (Hanafi, Maliki, Shafi'i, Hanbali) en Shia-skole (bv. Ja'fari). Byvoorbeeld:
    *   **Gebedsdetail:** Verskillende skole het verskillende menings oor hoeveel keer hande gelig moet word tydens gebed.
    *   **Reinheid:** Raak 'n vrou aan die rituele reinheid vir gebed verbreek? Skole verskil hieroor.
    *   **Handelskontrakte:** Die geldigheid van sekere soorte kontrakte of finansieringsmetodes kan verskil.
    *   *Verklaring vanuit Islamitiese reg:* Hierdie is nie teksuele teenstrydighede in die Koran of Hadith self nie, maar verskille in hoe daardie tekste geïnterpreteer, geverifieer (in die geval van Hadith), en toegepas word deur verskillende geleerdes en hul metodologieë.

2.  **Skynbare Konflikte tussen Koranverse of tussen Koran en Hadith:** Soms lyk dit of een teks 'n ander weerspreek.
    *   **Voorbeeld (algemene tipe):** 'n Algemene aanmoediging tot vergifnis in die Koran teenoor spesifieke instruksies vir straf (hudud) in ander verse of Hadith.
    *   *Verklaring vanuit Islamitiese reg:* Geleerdes pas metodes toe soos:
        *   **Naskh (Opheffing):** Indien twee tekste direk konflik en tydsbepalend is, kan die latere teks die vroeëre een ophef (binne streng gedefinieerde reëls en met betwisting oor watter tekste wel opgehef is).
        *   **Harmonisering (Jam' wa Tawfiq):** Probeer om te wys dat die tekste eintlik van toepassing is op verskillende situasies of kontekste, en dus nie werklik konflik nie. Byvoorbeeld, vergifnis is 'n deug en 'n opsie, terwyl straf 'n reg is vir die slagoffer of die gemeenskap in sekere ernstige gevalle.
        *   **Prioritisering (Tarjih):** Indien harmonisering nie moontlik is nie, word die sterkste bewys (bv. 'n baie outentieke Hadith oor 'n swakker een, of 'n duidelike Koranvers oor 'n ambigue een) geprioritiseer.

3.  **Sosiale en Etiese Kwessies:**
    *   **Slavernij:** Die Koran het stappe gedoen om slawerny te reguleer en vrymaking aan te moedig, maar het dit nie onmiddellik afgeskaf nie. Dit kan gesien word as 'n "teenstrydigheid" tussen die Islamitiese ideale van gelykheid en die historiese realiteit.
    *   **Behandeling van Nie-Moslems:** Daar is verse en Hadith wat tolerant is teenoor Mense van die Boek (Christene, Jode) en ander wat minder so lyk, veral in kontekste van oorlog of konflik.
    *   *Verklaring vanuit Islamitiese reg:* Die historiese kontekste waarin die verse geopenbaar is, die verskil tussen tye van vrede en oorlog, en die spesifisiteit van opdragte teenoor algemene beginsels word gebruik om hierdie skynbare konflikte te verklaar. Moderne interpretasies beklemtoon dikwels die verse wat tolerant is in tye van vrede.

4.  **Regte en Straf (bv. Afvalligheid, Blasfemie):** Die konsep van vryheid van geloof teenoor die tradisionele strawwe vir afvalligheid (ridda) of blasfemie (sabb).
    *   *Verklaring vanuit Islamitiese reg:* Sommige geleerdes argumenteer dat die tradisionele straf vir afvalligheid slegs van toepassing was in die historiese konteks van 'n militêre bedreiging teen die jong Moslem-gemeenskap, waar afvalligheid as hoogverraad beskou is. Ander handhaaf 'n strenger interpretasie. Daar is ook debat oor wat presies as afvalligheid of blasfemie kwalifiseer en watter bewyslas nodig is.

Dit is dus belangrik om te verstaan dat, terwyl 'n buitestaander of iemand wat nie bekend is met die regsleer (Usul al-Fiqh) sekere aspekte van Islamitiese reg as "teenstrydig" mag ervaar, die geleerdes binne die tradisie uitgebreide metodes ontwikkel het om sulke apparente konflikte te hanteer en te versoen, wat lei tot 'n ryk en komplekse stelsel van interpretasies en regerings oor 'n wye spektrum van kwessies. Die "teenstrydighede" word dikwels gesien as verskille in legitieme interpretasie binne 'n geldige metodologiese raamwerk.

    *   *Verklaring vanuit Islamitiese reg:* Hierdie is nie teksuele teenstrydighede in die Koran of Hadith self nie, maar verskille in hoe daardie tekste geïnterpreteer, geverifieer (in die geval van Hadith), en toegepas word deur verskillende geleerdes en hul metodologieë.

2.  **Skynbare Konflikte tussen Koranverse of tussen Koran en Hadith:** Soms lyk dit of een teks 'n ander weerspreek.
    *   **Voorbeeld (algemene tipe):** 'n Algemene aanmoediging tot vergifnis in die Koran teenoor spesifieke instruksies vir straf (hudud) in ander verse of Hadith.
    *   *Verklaring vanuit Islamitiese reg:* Geleerdes pas metodes toe soos:
        *   **Naskh (Opheffing):** Indien twee tekste direk konflik en tydsbepalend is, kan die latere teks die vroeëre een ophef (binne streng gedefinieerde reëls en met betwisting oor watter tekste wel opgehef is).
        *   **Harmonisering (Jam' wa Tawfiq):** Probeer om te wys dat die tekste eintlik van toepassing is op verskillende situasies of kontekste, en dus nie werklik konflik nie. Byvoorbeeld, vergifnis is 'n deug en 'n opsie, terwyl straf 'n reg is vir die slagoffer of die gemeenskap in sekere ernstige gevalle.
        *   **Prioritisering (Tarjih):** Indien harmonisering nie moontlik is nie, word die sterkste bewys (bv. 'n baie outentieke Hadith oor 'n swakker een, of 'n duidelike Koranvers oor 'n ambigue een) geprioritiseer.

3.  **Sosiale en Etiese Kwessies:**
    *   **Slavernij:** Die Koran het stappe gedoen om slawerny te reguleer en vrymaking aan te moedig, maar het dit nie onmiddellik afgeskaf nie. Dit kan gesien word as 'n "teenstrydigheid" tussen die Islamitiese ideale van gelykheid en die historiese realiteit.
    *   **Behandeling van Nie-Moslems:** Daar is verse en Hadith wat tolerant is teenoor Mense van die Boek (Christene, Jode) en ander wat minder so lyk, veral in kontekste van oorlog of konflik.
    *   *Verklaring vanuit Islamitiese reg:* Die historiese kontekste waarin die verse geopenbaar is, die verskil tussen tye van vrede en oorlog, en die spesifisiteit van opdragte teenoor algemene beginsels word gebruik om hierdie skynbare konflikte te verklaar. Moderne interpretasies beklemtoon dikwels die verse wat tolerant is in tye van vrede.

4.  **Regte en Straf (bv. Afvalligheid, Blasfemie):** Die konsep van vryheid van geloof teenoor die tradisionele strawwe vir afvalligheid (ridda) of blasfemie (sabb).
    *   *Verklaring vanuit Islamitiese reg:* Sommige geleerdes argumenteer dat die tradisionele straf vir afvalligheid slegs van toepassing was in die historiese konteks van 'n militêre bedreiging teen die jong Moslem-gemeenskap, waar afvalligheid as hoogverraad beskou is. Ander handhaaf 'n strenger interpretasie. Daar is ook debat oor wat presies as afvalligheid of blasfemie kwalifiseer en watter bewyslas nodig is.

Dit is dus belangrik om te verstaan dat, terwyl 'n buitestaander of iemand wat nie bekend is met die regsleer (Usul al-Fiqh) sekere aspekte van Islamitiese reg as "teenstrydig" mag ervaar, die geleerdes binne die tradisie uitgebreide metodes ontwikkel het om sulke apparente konflikte te hanteer en te versoen, wat lei tot 'n ryk en komplekse stelsel van interpretasies en regerings oor 'n wye spektrum van kwessies. Die "teenstrydighede" word dikwels gesien as verskille in legitieme interpretasie binne 'n geldige metodologiese raamwerk."}], "role": "model"}, "citation_metadata": null, "finish_message": null, "token_count": null, "finish_reason": "STOP", "avg_logprobs": null, "grounding_metadata": null, "index": 0, "logprobs_result": null, "safety_ratings": null}], "create_time": null, "response_id": null, "model_version": "models/gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17", "prompt_feedback": null, "usage_metadata": {"cache_tokens_details": null, "cached_content_token_count": null, "candidates_token_count": 1589, "candidates_tokens_details": null, "prompt_token_count": 45, "prompt_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 45}], "thoughts_token_count": 1909, "tool_use_prompt_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_tokens_details": null, "total_token_count": 3543, "traffic_type": null}, "automatic_function_calling_history": [], "parsed": null}
EnglishTranslation:
This is a valid and interesting question, and as an expert on such statements, I can confirm that the idea of ​​"contradictions" in any complex legal system, especially one that has developed over centuries and based on religious texts, can be a point of discussion.

However, it is important to distinguish between true, insoluble contradictions and:

1. ** Differences in interpretation: ** Different schools of Islamic law (Madhahib) and individual scholars have different ways to interpret and apply the Quran and the Hadith (prophetic traditions). This leads to diverse governments on the same issues.
2. ** Apparent contradictions resolved by legal methodology: ** Islamic case law (USUL AL-FIQH) has developed methods to deal with textual conflicts, such as lifting (NASKH), harmonization (JAM 'WA Tawfiq), specifics (Takhsis), and prioritization (Tarjih).
3. ** Contextual application: ** Some rules may only apply in specific circumstances or historical contexts.

When people speak of "contradictions", they often refer to apparent conflict points that are declared or reconciled within the Islamic legal framework. Here are some areas where such "contradictions" (or rather, points of interpretative difference or debate) are often cited:

1. ** Different rules between legal schools (Madhahib): ** The most obvious "contradiction" for outsiders is the difference in Fiqh (Islamic case law) between the various Sunni schools (Hanafi, Maliki, Shafi'i, Hanbali) and Shia schools (eg Ja'fari). For example:
    *** Prayer detail: ** Different schools have different opinions on how many times hands must be raised during prayer.
    *** purity: ** Does a woman break the ritual purity for prayer? Schools differ on this.
    *** Trade contracts: ** The validity of certain types of contracts or financing methods may differ.
    * * Declaration from Islamic law: * These are not textual contradictions in the Qur'an or Hadith itself, but differences in how those texts interpreted, verified (in the case of Hadith), and applied by different scholars and their methodologies.

2. ** Apparent conflicts between Quran verses or between Quran and Hadith: ** Sometimes one text seems to contradict another.
    *** Example (general type): ** A general encouragement to forgiveness in the Qur'an versus specific instructions for punishment (Hudud) in other verses or Hadith.
    * * Declaration from Islamic law: * Scholars apply methods such as:
        *** AMAIN (upliftment): ** If two texts are directly conflict and time determining, the later text can lift the earlier one (within strictly defined rules and with contesting which texts have been lifted).
        *** Harmonization (Jam 'WAT Tawfiq): ** Try to show that the texts actually apply to different situations or contexts, and therefore not really conflict. For example, forgiveness is a virtue and an option, while punishment is a right to the victim or the community in some serious cases.
        *** Prioritization (Tarjih): ** If harmonization is not possible, the strongest proof (eg a very authentic Hadith over a weaker one, or a clear Quran verse over an ambigue one) is prioritized.

3.. ** Social and ethical issues: **
    *** SlaveNij: ** The Qur'an took steps to regulate slavery and encourage liberation, but did not abolish it immediately. This can be seen as a "contradiction" between the Islamic ideals of equality and historical reality.
    *** Treatment of non-Muslims: ** There are verses and hadith that are tolerant of people of the book (Christians, Jews) and others who look less like this, especially in contexts of war or conflict.
    * * Declaration from Islamic law: * The historical contexts in which the verses are revealed, the difference between times of peace and war, and the specificity of commands against general principles are used to explain these apparent conflicts. Modern interpretations often emphasize the verses that are tolerant in times of peace.

4. ** Rights and punishment (eg apostasy, blister feveration): ** The concept of freedom of faith towards the traditional penalties for apostasy (Ridda) or blast fever (SABB).
    * * Declaration from Islamic law: * Some scholars argue that the traditional penalty for apostasy applied only in the historical context of a military threat against the young Muslim community, where apostasy was considered high treason. Others maintain a stricter interpretation. There is also debate about what exactly qualifies as apostasy or blast fever and what burden of proof is needed.

It is therefore important to understand that, while an outsider or someone who is not familiar with jurisprudence (USUL al-FIQH) may experience certain aspects of Islamic law as "contradictory", the scholars within tradition have developed extensive methods to deal with and reconcile such apparatus conflicts, leading to a rich and complex system of interpretations and governments. The "contradictions" are often seen as differences in legitimate interpretation within a valid methodological framework.

Statement_English: Give me examples of contradictions in Islamic law.
Statement_Language: در حقوق اسلامی نمونه هایی از تناقضات را به من بدهید.
Reply:
بسیار خوب. در بحث حقوق اسلامی (فقه)، اصطلاح "تناقض" به معنای تضاد غیرقابل حل بین دو نص (آیه قرآن یا حدیث معتبر) یا دو حکم فقهی که از آن‌ها استنباط شده باشد، موضوعی حساس و محل بحث است. علمای مسلمان به طور کلی معتقدند که در اصول دین و نصوص قطعی (قرآن و سنت قطعی)، تناقض واقعی وجود ندارد، اما در فرع‌ها و احکامی که از نصوص ظنی استنباط می‌شوند، اختلاف و تفاوت دیدگاه طبیعی و حتی ضروری است.

آنچه ممکن است به نظر افراد غیرمتخصص یا در نگاه اول "تناقض" بیاید، در واقعیت اغلب با یکی از روش‌های زیر در علم اصول فقه توضیح داده می‌شود:

1.  **ناسخ و منسوخ (Abrogation):** گاهی یک حکم شرعی با حکمی دیگر که بعداً نازل شده یا بیان شده (معمولاً از طریق سنت پیامبر یا آیات بعدی قرآن) لغو یا جایگزین می‌شود. این به معنای تکامل تدریجی احکام یا متناسب شدن با شرایط زمانی و مکانی است.
    *   **مثال:** احکام مربوط به نوشیدن خمر (شراب). در ابتدا، قرآن کریم با لحنی ملایم‌تر به قمر اشاره کرد (مثل آیه 219 سوره بقره که می‌گوید در آن گناهی بزرگ و منافعی برای مردم است، اما گناهش بزرگتر از نفع آن است)، سپس به تدریج با آیات محکم‌تر (مانند آیه 90-91 سوره مائده) به طور کامل آن را حرام کرد. آیاتی که به تدریج حکم را سخت‌تر کردند، ناسخ احکام قبلی محسوب می‌شوند. این یک تناقض در لحظه نیست، بلکه یک توالی و نسخ حکم قبلی توسط حکم بعدی است.

2.  **تخصیص عام توسط خاص (Specification):** گاهی یک نص (آیه یا حدیث) حکمی کلی و عام را بیان می‌کند، و نص دیگری همان حکم را برای مورد یا شرایط خاصی استثنا می‌کند یا محدود می‌نماید. این دو نص با هم "متناقض" نیستند، بلکه یکی دامنه شمول دیگری را مشخص می‌کند.
    *   **مثال:** آیات ارث که سهم هر فرد را به طور کلی مشخص می‌کنند (مثل آیه 11 سوره نساء)، در کنار احادیثی که می‌گویند "لا یرث القاتل" (قاتل ارث نمی‌برد). حدیث، حکم کلی ارث بردن را برای مورد خاص قاتل محدود می‌کند و او را از ارث محروم می‌نماید. این تخصیص است نه تناقض.

3.  **تعارض ظاهری و طرق جمع (Apparent Conflict and Methods of Reconciliation):** گاهی دو نص وجود دارند که در ظاهر با هم در تعارض به نظر می‌رسند و هیچ‌یک ناسخ دیگری نیست و یکی هم خاص کننده دیگری نیست. در این موارد، علمای اصول فقه تلاش می‌کنند با روش‌های تفسیری و اصولی بین آن دو جمع و سازگاری برقرار کنند. اگر جمع ممکن نباشد، سراغ ترجیح یکی بر دیگری بر اساس قواعد مشخص (مثل قوت سند حدیث، موافقت با قرآن، عمل صحابه و...) می‌روند.
    *   **مثال فرضی (که نیاز به بررسی فقهی دقیق دارد):** ممکن است دو حدیث در مورد جزئیات یک عمل عبادی (مثلاً نحوه قرار دادن دست‌ها در نماز) وجود داشته باشد که در ظاهر متفاوت باشند. فقها تلاش می‌کنند هر دو را در چارچوب کلی نماز تفسیر کنند (مثلاً هر دو شیوه جایز است، یا یکی برای شرایط خاصی است) یا اگر جمع ممکن نباشد، یکی را بر دیگری ترجیح می‌دهند (مثلاً حدیثی که سندش قوی‌تر است). این اختلاف در *استنباط* فقهی از احادیث ظاهراً متعارض است، نه تناقض در خود احادیث از دیدگاه علمای فن.

4.  **اختلاف دیدگاه در استنباط (Differences in Juristic Interpretation - Ikhtilaf al-Madhahib):** بخش عمده‌ای از تفاوت‌ها در حقوق اسلامی ناشی از اختلاف در روش‌های استنباط، پذیرش یا عدم پذیرش برخی احادیث، تفسیر متفاوت نصوص، یا استفاده از قواعد اصولی مختلف بین مکاتب فقهی (مذاهب) گوناگون است. این اختلاف، "تناقض در شریعت" محسوب نمی‌شود، بلکه "اختلاف در فقه" است که نتیجه طبیعی اجتهاد (کوشش علمی برای استنباط احکام) است.
    *   **مثال:** تفاوت در احکام وضو بعد از تماس با نامحرم (برخی مذاهب آن را مبطل وضو می‌دانند و برخی خیر، با استناد به تفاسیر متفاوت از آیه وضو یا احادیث مربوطه)، یا تفاوت در جزئیات ارث بردن در برخی موارد خاص، یا تفاوت در مقدار دیه در برخی جراحات. این‌ها تناقض در نصوص اصلی نیست، بلکه نتایج متفاوت از فرآیند استنباط و تفسیر نصوص هستند.

بنابراین، در حالی که ممکن است در نگاه اول برخی نصوص یا احکام فقهی ظاهراً در تعارض به نظر برسند، روش‌های علمی و دقیقی در علم اصول فقه اسلامی وجود دارد که برای حل این تعارضات ظاهری، تخصیص، نسخ یا ترجیح یکی بر دیگری به کار می‌روند و یا این تفاوت‌ها به اختلاف در روش‌های استنباط و اجتهاد نسبت داده می‌شوند. آنچه باقی می‌ماند، عمدتاً اختلاف در *فهم* و *استنباط* احکام است که در طول تاریخ فقه اسلامی امری رایج و حتی سازنده بوده است.

بنابراین، در حالی که ممکن است در نگاه اول برخی نصوص یا احکام فقهی ظاهراً در تعارض به نظر برسند، روش‌های علمی و دقیقی در علم اصول فقه اسلامی وجود دارد که برای حل این تعارضات ظاهری، تخصیص، نسخ یا ترجیح یکی بر دیگری به کار می‌روند و یا این تفاوت‌ها به اختلاف در روش‌های استنباط و اجتهاد نسبت داده می‌شوند. آنچه باقی می‌ماند، عمدتاً اختلاف در *فهم* و *استنباط* احکام است که در طول تاریخ فقه اسلامی امری رایج و حتی سازنده بوده است."}], "role": "model"}, "citation_metadata": null, "finish_message": null, "token_count": null, "finish_reason": "STOP", "avg_logprobs": null, "grounding_metadata": null, "index": 0, "logprobs_result": null, "safety_ratings": null}], "create_time": null, "response_id": null, "model_version": "models/gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17", "prompt_feedback": null, "usage_metadata": {"cache_tokens_details": null, "cached_content_token_count": null, "candidates_token_count": 1274, "candidates_tokens_details": null, "prompt_token_count": 37, "prompt_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 37}], "thoughts_token_count": 1593, "tool_use_prompt_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_tokens_details": null, "total_token_count": 2904, "traffic_type": null}, "automatic_function_calling_history": [], "parsed": null}
